node.title: Vibing on Art and Artists’ Books
node.description: Gil Gentile asked Hannah Mandel on a first date to a conceptual art exhibit at the Jewish Museum. A year later they created an artist’s book as a nod to it.
node.content: ["Gil Moshe Gentile got it just right in June 2013 when he asked Hannah Marie Mandel to meet him at \u201cJack Goldstein X 10,000,\u201d a conceptual art exhibit at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan.", "\u201cHe was an artist I really loved,\u201d Mr. Gentile said. \u201cIt was her vibe, too.\u201d", "When he had reached out to Ms. Mandel on OkCupid a week or so earlier, he had no idea that she was into \u201970s and \u201980s conceptual art. Her profile no less intrigued him \u2014 it was as sparse as his, and mentioned she created artist\u2019s books.", "At the time, he worked as an assistant to Cory Arcangel, a media post-conceptual artist, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, who was also on her artistic radar.", "\u201cWe both did small press projects,\u201d said Mr. Gentile, 33, now the exhibition and publications designer at the University Art Museum at SUNY Albany. He graduated from Sarah Lawrence.", "\u201cI was interested in conceptual art related to cinema,\u201d said Ms. Mandel, 31, now the archivist at the Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. A graduate of the Maryland Institute College of Art, she received a master\u2019s degree in library and information science from the University of California, Los Angeles.", "After wandering around the museum, they headed to Koreatown and had bibimbap, a Korean rice dish (she for the first time).", "\u201cIt felt like a really good match,\u201d said Ms. Mandel, who realized they knew some of the same people in the world of artists\u2019 books.", "They later took the subway home to Brooklyn \u2014 he to Bedford-Stuyvesant and she to Greenpoint \u2014 and met again a week later at Manhattan Inn, a former Greenpoint bar. Soon enough, their relationship developed a rhythm.", "He met her after work several times a week when she worked at Chelsea galleries managing photography, press and their websites. They regularly went to Printed Matter, an art bookstore in Chelsea, then to dinner at a Vietnamese restaurant in Chinatown or Veselka in the East Village. And just about every weekend, they went to one friend or another\u2019s art show opening.", "[Click here to binge read this week\u2019s featured couples.]", "In 2014 the couple created \u201cBrand New,\u201d an artist\u2019s book, by reprinting distorted photos from a 1985 New Museum catalog, including works by Jack Goldstein. It was a \u201csly\u201d nod, he said, to their first date.", "In 2015 Ms. Mandel moved into Mr. Gentile\u2019s apartment. A year later, after she got into an archival master\u2019s program at U.C.L.A., they moved to Los Angeles. (He grew up there, she in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.).", "They found a studio apartment in the Los Feliz neighborhood, and enjoyed hiking nearby trails up to Griffith Observatory and going over to his parents\u2019 house for Shabbat dinners.", "\u201cI really liked L.A. and planned that we would stay there,\u201d said Ms. Mandel. But after they landed jobs in 2018 back East \u2014 she at Bard and he at SUNY Albany \u2014 they moved to Hudson, N.Y.", "That fall they adopted Sesame, a rescue beagle cattle dog with \u201ca big personality,\u201d Mr. Gentile said, and Ms. Mandel\u2019s passion for baking postmodern-like cakes took off into a side business, Forsythia Forsythia.", "Mr. Gentile asked Ms. Mandel to marry him on July 3, 2019, as they relaxed at home playing with Sesame. A celebratory dinner followed at Lil\u2019 Deb\u2019s Oasis, their favorite restaurant in Hudson, after which he got down on one knee for a formal proposal \u201cto have the experience of saying we did it,\u201d she said.", "They planned to get married in May 2020 at Joe\u2019s Garage, an event space in Catskill, N.Y., but after Covid hit they moved the date to December, which they postponed again.", "On Oct. 16, Rabbi Nina H. Mandel, a paternal aunt of the bride, officiated before 84 vaccinated guests. Their grandmothers watched on Zoom. So did the bride\u2019s father, who tuned in from an Albany hospital while recovering from a heart attack he had after arriving in New York a few days earlier. Her mother, along with the groom\u2019s mother and father, attended in person.", "\u201cFull speed ahead,\u201d Ms. Mandel recalled her father saying before they were wed that rainy evening under a huppah he had built.", "At the reception, out came a creation of the bride: a white-tiered, tahini-frosted coconut and black sesame cake filled with pickled berry jam. It was decorated with marzipan apples and oranges, a salute to New York and California."]
